DataElement.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Mutation Individual Highest Prior Probability Percentage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The highest probability of a patient or subject in a family to develop a breast cancer gene mutation. [Manually-curated]

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Mutation Individual Highest Prior Probability
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The maximum previously calculated probability of developing a breast cancer gene mutation through use of a conceptual model. [Manually-curated]

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002:Genetic alterations found in the neoplastic lesions of the animal model. These alterations are not made intentionally.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.
Genetic alterations found in the neoplastic lesions of the animal model. These alterations are not made intentionally.
